byline.contributor: Jennifer Crossley Howard contributed reporting from Monroeville, Ala., and Ginia Bellafante from New York. Elisa Cho and Alain Delaquérière contributed research from New York.
byline.original: By ALEXANDRA ALTER and SERGE F. KOVALESKI

abstract: Discovery and publication of Go Set a Watchman, long-awaited second novel by author Harper Lee, ignites fierce debate; fans voice concerns over delayed release, whether book will stand up to classic To Kill a Mockingbird and whether aged novelist was coerced into publication; Lee issues statement saying she is happy with outcome, while those close to her say she was hurt by allegations about her credibility and decision making.
lead_paragraph: The plan to publish “Go Set a Watchman” has ignited fierce debate, but Ms. Lee’s lawyer, Tonja B. Carter, and other friends say the author is capable of making up her own mind.

headline.main: After Harper Lee Novel Surfaces, Plots Arise
headline.print_headline: After Harper Lee Novel Surfaces, Plots Arise

snippet: The plan to publish “Go Set a Watchman” has ignited fierce debate, but Ms. Lee’s lawyer, Tonja B. Carter, and other friends say the author is capable of making up her own mind.
